---------------------------------------------------------------------
Three Canadian soldiers have been shipped out to Afghanistan and
are based deep in the heart of the conflict: Kandahar Province,
where the Taliban insurgency is fiercest. Every day, Canadian
soldiers on the ground confront the chaos and violence of life
"outside the wire". They donÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t have the big picture; theyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢re not
interested in the policy. TheyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢re just trying to help the people,
protect each other...and survive.

Afghanada gives us a gruntsÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢-eye-view of the conflict . The sound
is edgy and gritty, the impact immediate, pushing the listener into
an auditory journey that is impossible to escape. It is a
reflection of the very real situation Canadian soldiers are facing
every day in Afghanistan.

----

The Afghanada cast includes Billy MacLellan as Private Lucas
"Chucky" Manson, Jenny Young as Sergeant Pat "Coach" Kinsella, Paul
Fauteux as Private Dean "The Machine" Donaldson, Jordan Pettle as
Corporal Jakes, Anousha Alamian as Sami and Khan Soroor.

----

Episode 01:

The series begins with five Canadian soldiers and a translator
traveling from Kandahar to a local village to establish contact and
deliver supplies to a school. Following a successful meeting with
village elders, (a shura,) they proceed to the school but are
intercepted by the Taliban. One member of the unit disappears.

Episode 02:

The Sergeant is missing in action. Master Corporal Pat Kinsella, a
female combat soldier, is made temporary section commander. The
section is ordered back to base. On the way back, they are marooned
in the desert when their Light Armoured Vehicle (LAV) falls into a
dry river bed during a sandstorm. They make a surprise discovery in
a cave in a mountainside following a strange encounter with a lone
American soldier.

Episode 03:

While returning to base from a medical mission, an Improvised
Explosive Device (IED) explodes, disabling their LAV. The section
comes under attack when an attempt to borrow a tractor from a local
farmer goes sideways. They are rescued by American firepower.

Episode 04:

Assigned to American command, the section is tasked with hunting
for suicide bomb factories in Kandahar. Following a raid on an
Afghan family, (who could be suicide bombers), the unit comes to a
mosque and meets a rogue American unit which they suspect is
involved in shady operations. They must decide whether to blow the
whistle or not.

Episode 05:

Prior to a major offensive, Kinsella is replaced as temporary
section commander by Master Corporal Jakes from the Provincial
Reconstruction Team. He must gain the trust of the unit in the
midst of battle. His lack of experience under fire highlights the
consequences of his decisions for the unit.

Episode 06:

Engaged in the NATO offensive against the Taliban, the unit
encounters a small group of Afghan National Police (ANP) doing
their best to keep law and order without equipment or supplies.
Their attempt to aid the ANP by destroying some Taliban weapons
caches embroils them in local tribal politics and worsens the local
situation.

Episode 07:

The section is assigned with providing security on a Village
Medical Outreach (VMO). The goal is to improve conditions in rural
areas and gain the support of the local Afghan population. They run
afoul of Islamic law while attempting to save a teenage girl who
has a fatal infection.

Episode 08:

Christmas at Kandahar Airfield looks better than being stuck at an
abandoned American firebase in the mountains on the Pakistan
border. In the valley below is a madrassa, that doubles as a
Taliban training base. While waiting for a possible attack, Private
Donaldson struggles with the psychological effects of killing an
enemy fighter.

Episode 09:

The Section splits up for the first time in months to take a few
days leave. Dean and Lucas fly out to blow off steam in Bangkok and
Sergeant Kinsella heads home to Prince Rupert to see her parents
and her boyfriend. The boys have a great time sampling many
delights forbidden on the job in Afghanistan. Kinsella on the other
hand finds re-integration into civilian life a complicated
experience.

Episode 10:

Outside the wire once again, the Section heads out on a clandestine
operation to find and destroy a Taliban command post. This time
they have a new interpreter recruited from a local village. When
the ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œterpÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ begins to consider the risk his family faces from the
Taliban now that he is helping the NATO forces, he makes a decision
that endangers the Section. Private Manson rushes to his defense
even though it means disobeying a senior officer.

Episode 11:

After barely surviving a river crossing when the bridge collapses
under their LAV, the Section finds itself marooned in a remote
village. A Canadian aid agency has been hard at work here and the
village has been turned into a thriving community, the likes of
which they have not seen before. One of the aid workers takes a
shine to Dean, but the Taliban are not impressed with the success
of this village and things go horribly wrong.

Episode 12:

A hearts and minds mission to deliver food aid turns into a quest
for the elusive Mullah Omar, leader of the Taliban. Along the way
they encounter a former Russian soldier and a strange group of
women farmers. Do they get Omar in the end? Only time will tell.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
The album graphics are from another Afghanada encoded at 192 kbps.
I don't know who's rip that is or who scanned them, but I've
included them here for those who might want them.
